Increased Thyrotoxicosis causes increased sensitivity to catecholamines due to increased expression of β 1 -adrenergic receptors as well as changes in proteins controlling post β 1 -adrenergic receptor activity', 'ankihub_id': 'c42f4587-49f0-46a9-a4ee-b2520f979793'}, {'anki_id': 1462380628768.0, 'document': 'One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is hypertension , which is a result of an upregulation of α 1 -adrenergic receptors , causing increased sensitivity of blood vessels to catecholamines Cortisol mediates the upregulation of α 1 receptors on arterioles', 'ankihub_id': 'b3fa292b-8c06-4660-9753-9d6cfb475cf2'}, {'anki_id': 1475636975592.0, 'document': 'Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with anuria and/or heart failure', 'ankihub_id': 'b7067274-3eeb-46d9-9618-e71bc0b60246'}, {'anki_id': 1503264783060.0, 'document': 'Rifabutin induces::induces or inhibits cytochrome P450 - **Less potent CYP450 activator when compared to rifampin - Can therefore decrease concentration of drugs such as anti-epileptics and warfarin that use CYP450 for metabolism', 'ankihub_id': '404db30a-24aa-40b5-a9b5-c8717a88b1e0'}, {'anki_id': 1475784401111.0, 'document': 'Loop diuretics may be used to treat the symptoms of pulmonary edema in an acute heart failure exacerbation', 'ankihub_id': '83fd7aad-386f-4ca6-b822-2a6f4562c68c'}, {'anki_id': 1489962674114.0, 'document': 'Side effects of danazol include weight gain, edema, acne , hirsutism , and masculinization ( androgenic effects)', 'ankihub_id': 'b126d7b5-48de-4738-b671-03b6115bb280'}, {'anki_id': 1485389822615.0, 'document': 'Triptans are contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) or Prinzmetal angina AKA vasospastic angina', 'ankihub_id': '950b39a8-88e4-49a8-b623-5a228b579b03'}]

[{'anki_id': 1461601445180.0, 'document': 'Side effects of metoclopramide include extrapyramidal effects such as dystonia, akathisia, and parkinsonian features as a result of central D 2 blockade - First-generation (H1) antihistamine can be used to reduce these symptoms via their anticholinergic activity - Metoclopramide causes dopamine receptor blockade in the basal ganglia - Cause excess cholinergic activity - Manifests as significant extrapyramidal symptoms ADAPT : A cute D ystonia; A kathisia; P arkinsonism; T ardive dyskinesia', 'ankihub_id': '30d014df-391d-4eca-8f2c-101440f940e6'}, {'anki_id': 1461616635772.0, 'document': 'The H 2 receptor antagonist cimetidine is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome P-450 and therefore has multiple drug interactions Cimetidine can also cross the blood-brain barrier (causing confusion, dizziness, and headaches) and placenta', 'ankihub_id': '95cc2cd1-e582-4b3c-b59b-efb08750c67d'}, {'anki_id': 1485389798509.0, 'document': 'Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan) are 5-HT 1B,D receptor agonists', 'ankihub_id': 'f65719be-2043-4dad-b8e0-1950d66b6ee1'}, {'anki_id': 1461806905197.0, 'document': 'Misoprostol is a PGE 1 analog that may be used to prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcers NSAIDs block production of PGE 1 at the stomach mucosa, which utilizes PGE 1 to help vasodilate vessels that supply it (thus bringing more nutrients to help repair/grow)', 'ankihub_id': 'd2558c0b-8b89-4677-bbca-da5d603eb7c8'}, {'anki_id': 1463883769980.0, 'document': 'Glucocorticoids inhibit production of inflammatory leukotrienes by lipoxygenase', 'ankihub_id': '7cf7f593-07c0-4255-b92e-4b7fcee3a3e9'}, {'anki_id': 1482978386661.0, 'document': 'Cholelithiasis may arise due to decreased phospholipids and/or bile acids One example of a phospholipid is phosphatidylcholine', 'ankihub_id': 'bdbab618-beb6-4c64-9583-4415839cf571'}, {'anki_id': 1461601301851.0, 'document': 'Side effects of metoclopramide include drowsiness and depression as a result of central D 2 blockade', 'ankihub_id': 'c837680b-a8a8-450e-bbd9-b4253ee45668'}, {'anki_id': 1495883084332.0, 'document': 'What type of upper airway obstruction is seen in anaphylaxis ? Fixed upper airway obstruction (due to laryngeal edema) Physical exam may reveal stridor and harsh respiratory sounds; however, wheezing is typically absent', 'ankihub_id': '8758b308-f0b4-4d39-a838-f677beddaa11'}, {'anki_id': 1487642795725.0, 'document': 'Which cytokine is produced by macrophages to recruit neutrophils for persistent acute inflammation ? IL-8 Persistent acute inflammation is marked by persistent pus formation', 'ankihub_id': 'b6cf925e-4fe8-415f-a326-8c2d6f4db6c0'}, {'anki_id': 1499356681362.0, 'document': 'Misoprostol is a synthetic PGE 1 analog which can be used to promote uterine contraction for the purpose of terminating pregnancy - When given for pregnancy termination, combine with mifepristone (administered 24-48 hours apart) - Can also be used for facilitating labor (off-label)', 'ankihub_id': '8e139d95-68a0-48ed-88c3-984145291cf0'}, {'anki_id': 1463172108621.0, 'document': 'Anovulatory cycles lead to the breakdown and shedding of proliferative glands resulting in abnormal uterine bleeding - PALM-C O EIN - Most common causes of anovulation: pregnancy, polycystic ovary syndrome, obesity, HPO axis abnormalities/immaturity, premature ovarian failure, hyperprolactinemia, thyroid disorders, eating disorders, competitive athletics, Cushing syndrome, adrenal insufficiency, chromosomal abnormalities (Turner syndrome) - No ovulation means no corpus luteum formation and thus no progesterone is released to modify / maintain the endometrium', 'ankihub_id': '8513a493-8ca7-4297-8bad-ad37bd82af21'}, {'anki_id': 1474571737889.0, 'document': '1st generation H 1 receptor antagonists may antagonize muscarinic receptors , leading to significant anticholinergic effects e.g., pupillary dilation, dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, exacerbation of glaucoma, and delirium', 'ankihub_id': '941770d7-ff33-455a-95ca-801dd8ab7363'}, {'anki_id': 1461616648667.0, 'document': 'The H 2 receptor antagonist cimetidine has many anti- androgenic effects (e.g., gynecomastia, impotence, elevated prolactin levels) Elevated prolactin levels may subsequently cause galactorrhea; anti-androgenic effects may also cause decreased libido in males', 'ankihub_id': '9a6c4393-92ad-40e6-8f74-66a3e47acb35'}, {'anki_id': 1518400898379.0, 'document': 'Low levels of α-fetoprotein (AFP) are seen in trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) and in trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) Trisomy Patau (13) Edward (18) Down (21) First Trimester β-hCG ↓ ↓ ↑ PAPP-A ↓ ↓ ↓ Second Trimester β-hCG ↔ ↓ ↑ Inhibin A ↔ ↔ or ↓ ↑ α-fetoprotein (AFP) ↔ ↓ ↓ Estriol ↔ ↓ ↓', 'ankihub_id': '7a280728-4761-4f17-8350-bf58a83bfc7f'}, {'anki_id': 1485389803104.0, 'document': 'Triptans induce vaso constriction of cerebral and meningeal vessels', 'ankihub_id': '39621ec8-588b-4834-ac5e-e0fef6809672'}, {'anki_id': 1557513437294.0, 'document': 'Triptan and ergot or another triptan = excessive vasoconstriction and HTN/MI/stroke - Overactivation of 5-HT receptors - Dihydroergotamine is the ergot used in migraine treatment. However, it is not frequently used due to its significant side effect profile, including gangrene and vasospastic (Prinzmetal) angina - Bromocriptine is also an ergot derivative. Both come from the ergot fungi. Thus, do not use triptans + an ergot derivative, or two ergot derivatives together. Do not use these drugs in the setting of uncontrolled hypertension either. Hence, this is why non-ergot dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole) are preferred in Parkinson disease', 'ankihub_id': '344ffa48-e954-4527-9a9f-49e6b241f319'}, {'anki_id': 1658871900153.0, 'document': "What drug may cause a transient and benign darkening of the stool and/or tongue? Bismuth subsalicylate - Used to treat diarrhea, heartburn, nausea, traveler's diarrhea, and/or in H. pylori quadruple therapy - Oral iron supplementation may also cause a a benign darkening of stool", 'ankihub_id': '0163eaa9-1123-4d41-9be1-3e4a719a65dc'}, {'anki_id': 1482289502594.0, 'document': 'Meckel diverticulum arises due to persistence of the vitelline duct AKA omphalomesenteric duct', 'ankihub_id': '057a4790-7ec8-4c0b-a148-41e7feea0de2'}, {'anki_id': 1509213102387.0, 'document': 'Mycophenolate mofetil can result in myelosuppression (-cytopenias)', 'ankihub_id': '22769959-ae13-42cd-83ab-53bf24ae35ea'}, {'anki_id': 1485389813213.0, 'document': 'Triptans inhibit trigeminal nerve activation', 'ankihub_id': 'e40df812-6230-4df0-82b7-707b5c58c12f'}, {'anki_id': 1461601568244.0, 'document': 'Metoclopramide may cause elevated prolactin levels , which can cause galactorrhea, impotence, gynecomastia, and menstrual disorders In the CNS, the hypothalamus uses dopamine to regulate prolactin secretion at the AP via action on D 2 receptors (G i - inhibits release)', 'ankihub_id': 'd2004f34-efc1-477d-8ffb-679dfb0021e3'}, {'anki_id': 1499356681125.0, 'document': "Alprostadil is used to maintain a(n) patent ductus arteriosus in the setting of certain types of congenital heart disease - PGE 1 is a vasodilator (and inhibitor of platelet aggregation) exerting potent smooth muscle relaxant effects - fetal ductus arteriosus normally depends on COX2 derived PGE2 to act locally on vasodilatory prostaglandin receptors (at birth PGE2 levels decline, allowing the ductus arteriosus to close but in certain types of congenital heart diseases it's important to maintain patency until surgery) - Administered by continuous infusion to keep ductus arteriosus open", 'ankihub_id': '33a703cd-3387-4c2e-b7ba-c1a62e766fc8'}, {'anki_id': 1499356681339.0, 'document': 'Misoprostol can be clinically used to treat gastric ulcers at high doses as it inhibits secretion of gastric acid - Misoprostol is a PGE1 mimic - At low doses promotes protective mucus secretion by gastric mucosa (but does not provide enough of a clinically relevant effect to be warranted at low doses)', 'ankihub_id': '7460755f-4bb5-4151-9887-0b20eac1d333'}, {'anki_id': 1485389807074.0, 'document': 'Triptans prevent the release of vasoactive peptides', 'ankihub_id': '37f67b0d-823e-4073-a087-a3e24592a2f8'}, {'anki_id': 1471541327679.0, 'document': 'Histamine causes arteriolar dilation and venous constriction Net effect is increased P c which increases filtration out of the capillaries (edema)', 'ankihub_id': '7a0b0390-3189-4731-95af-68d183f38b58'}, {'anki_id': 1461600845716.0, 'document': 'Metoclopramide antagonizes D 2 receptors in the area postrema (treats chemotherapy-induced vomiting) Also increases resting tone, contractility, lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone, and motility; does not influence colon transport time', 'ankihub_id': '0145fd12-97f6-4fab-8d9b-e7e65dea6bdd'}, {'anki_id': 1474580803822.0, 'document': 'Montelukast and zafirlukast are especially effective at treating aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease - Samter triad = asthma, nasal polyps, symptoms worsened by aspirin - Used to be known as aspirin-induced asthma', 'ankihub_id': '2326d00c-8fda-4dd8-806d-bfd0025796a8'}, {'anki_id': 1474571612120.0, 'document': 'Activation of the H 1 histamine receptor may cause pain , pruritus , and vasodilation', 'ankihub_id': '0693044e-cee1-44bd-b1d4-da86be6abb64'}, {'anki_id': 1556218968788.0, 'document': 'The treatment of an acute migraine refractory to NSAIDs in a patient with coronary artery disease may include prochlorperazine or metoclopramide (D 2 antagonists)::antiemetics Triptans / ergots may cause coronary vasospasm', 'ankihub_id': '18f6ad38-360d-404b-831e-39cb79c6669a'}, {'anki_id': 1557514244229.0, 'document': 'Overview of migraine treatment Prophylaxis, 1st-line : propranolol, topiramate, or valproate::3 Prophylaxis, 2nd-line : amitriptyline Abortive, mild : supportive / NSAIDs::2 Abortive, moderate-to-severe : triptans, ergots, antiemetics, or CGRP antagonists::4 - Never combine triptans and ergotamine due to their drug interaction profile (combination can lead to coronary vasospasm and serotonin syndrome) - Avoid topiramate, valproate, ergots, and triptans in pregnant patients', 'ankihub_id': '14b17977-f290-464e-b14e-1ce0ae0ed749'}, {'anki_id': 1487207105743.0, 'document': 'Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing cellular destruction by opsonizing the target with antibodies - e.g., autoimmune hemolytic anemia, ITP, transfusion reactions, hemolytic disease of the newborn - Can lead to phagocytosis or MAC mediated destruction, or NK antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity', 'ankihub_id': 'a4ffe149-6a6b-4fde-9e68-86400ff4f6d1'}, {'anki_id': 1487117266817.0, 'document': 'Which immunoglobulin contributes to immunity to worms by activating eosinophils ? IgE', 'ankihub_id': '190417d0-3caa-498e-882d-02ab0c8c2144'}, {'anki_id': 1509140057996.0, 'document': 'Medical abortions can be performed with a combination of mifepristone and misoprostol - Misoprostol is a PGE 1 analog - Mifepristone is a progesterone receptor antagonist - The combination of methotrexate (IM or oral) and misoprostol (oral or vaginal) is no longer recommended in the US as standard of care', 'ankihub_id': 'e6112705-6722-46bc-923c-b5c6163e886c'}, {'anki_id': 1473385372338.0, 'document': 'Erythropoietin (EPO) causes differentiation of proerythroblasts, which undergo further development to form mature erythrocytes Hypoxia → ↑ hypoxia-inducible factor 1α → ↑ EPO mRNA → ↑ EPO synthesis → ↑ proerythroblasts → ↑ erythrocytes', 'ankihub_id': '6e079eb2-772b-470e-90cc-41fa8283d1d7'}, {'anki_id': 1461599476879.0, 'document': 'Diphenhydramine and meclizine (1st generation H 1 receptor blockers) may cause significant sedation and have significant anti- muscarinic properties', 'ankihub_id': '6cd1939c-154e-422e-8ded-41af1c7cfc5f'}, {'anki_id': 1474571698024.0, 'document': '1st generation H 1 histamine r eceptor antagonists may be used to treat vestibular nausea and motion sickness e.g., diphenhydramine, meclizine', 'ankihub_id': '33327a02-0e02-4229-b9fe-20462cb585a5'}, {'anki_id': 1483930877881.0, 'document': 'The pathophysiology of migraine headaches is related to release of vasoactive peptides , substance P , and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP)', 'ankihub_id': '21c3fb26-f7a4-4268-bd0c-8f8ddcd80479'}, {'anki_id': 1505861447912.0, 'document': 'What anti-emetic agents may cause extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., acute dystonia) as a possible side effect? Metoclopramide and prochlorperazine::2 Both are dopamine antagonists; other EPS include akathisia and parkinsonism', 'ankihub_id': '2227c2de-db72-4f5a-894b-9cbf205885be'}, {'anki_id': 1474571630796.0, 'document': 'Histamine increases vascular permeability , which is responsible for urticaria/hives (H 1 receptor activation)', 'ankihub_id': '1bc03113-f0ee-4625-b65a-9b909d5aebcf'}, {'anki_id': 1461806938449.0, 'document': 'Misoprostol is contraindicated in patients of childbearing potential due to its abortifacient effects Misoprostol can be used to treat peptic ulcers and prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcers, but not commonly used due to its side effect of diarrhea', 'ankihub_id': '4235223b-ab1f-486a-96e7-d479310eda82'}, {'anki_id': 1473628107938.0, 'document': 'In an asthmatic response , mast cells release preformed histamine granules (early-phase reaction)', 'ankihub_id': 'aebb3954-6459-4c5f-89cd-81d177da3ef7'}, {'anki_id': 1462038836551.0, 'document': 'A useful initial therapy for hyperthyroidism is a(n) β-adrenergic blocking agent, such as propranolol Due to thyroid hormones upregulation of β 1 adrenergic receptors', 'ankihub_id': 'a5c6c68a-e3aa-46dd-b578-2cb759caa227'}, {'anki_id': 1487642714884.0, 'document': 'Destruction of phagocytosed material occurs through respiratory ( oxidative ) burst , which utilizes O 2 as a substrate', 'ankihub_id': 'debbd458-d299-4693-9103-1b59509f17c0'}, {'anki_id': 1488847815337.0, 'document': 'What class of anti-platelet drugs may cause thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) as an adverse effect? ADP receptor inhibitors - AKA P2Y12 inhibitors - e.g., -grel suffix / ticlopidine (strongest association with)', 'ankihub_id': '7fc312c1-6c6a-49d4-a774-f6560d5a4c86'}, {'anki_id': 1474571746097.0, 'document': '1st generation H 1 receptor antagonists may acutely suppress the extrapyramidal side effects associated with certain antipsychotic drugs - e.g., acute dystonia, drug-induced parkinsonism - Antimuscarinic effects re-establish dopaminergic-cholinergic balance', 'ankihub_id': '324d8647-3498-4817-a51f-2810dee925e2'}, {'anki_id': 1474571685484.0, 'document': 'Histamine mediates type I hypersensitivity reactions via activation of H 1 receptors', 'ankihub_id': 'fd3b18b8-77bf-423b-ac32-c97315e39fca'}, {'anki_id': 1475196629598.0, 'document': 'The H + from NH 4 + (glutamine breakdown) in the proximal tubule cells is secreted into the lumen via the Na + -H + exchanger', 'ankihub_id': '7fdb2a85-8a5e-4c16-a800-a18f015a9698'}, {'anki_id': 1474580773841.0, 'document': 'Leukotriene D4 exerts its effects by binding to the Cysteinyl leukotrienes 1 (CysLT1) receptor It is a GPCR', 'ankihub_id': '5fd54b59-9bbe-4fcf-bf09-44be610c529e'}, {'anki_id': 1487640101055.0, 'document': 'Arachidonic acids are converted to leukotrienes via the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase', 'ankihub_id': '26f94841-2636-4972-a894-e5fa5b32e0a9'}, {'anki_id': 1461615646774.0, 'document': 'What drug class do cimetidine , ranitidine , famotidine , and nizatidine belong to? H 2 receptor antagonists "- tidine " suffix', 'ankihub_id': 'a9ffe577-d401-4edb-96f8-d53b88dd0897'}, {'anki_id': 1489961629334.0, 'document': 'Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used to terminate pregnancy when combined with misoprostol (PGE 1 analog)', 'ankihub_id': '1380f6f0-76d8-4006-a110-40d3c5f6dcc3'}, {'anki_id': 1525397490946.0, 'document': 'When patients who have been chronically taking PPIs withdraw from usage, they may experience rebound gastric acid hypersecretion - Chronic PPI use leads to alkaline stomach environment that stimulates gastrin release, thus high gastrin levels will overstimulate the parietal cells with hyperfunctioning of unblocked ATPase - Rebound gastric hypersecretion will lead to reflux symptoms', 'ankihub_id': '5e3a4fdd-70b6-4123-8ed1-efb3e76aa4c0'}, {'anki_id': 1461600965249.0, 'document': 'Metoclopramide (D 2 antagonist) is contraindicated in patients with small bowel obstruction ::GI or Parkinson disease ::CNS Due to its prokinetic effects and potential to exacerbate motor symptoms', 'ankihub_id': '53aa0c15-bbff-4bfc-a87d-64d003b69403'}, {'anki_id': 1462061188088.0, 'document': 'Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects by inducing the synthesis of lipocortin-1 , an inhibitor of phospholipase A 2 Phospholipase A 2 provides the precursor (arachidonic acid) for the synthesis of prostaglandins and leukotrienes , which mediate the immune response', 'ankihub_id': '623dbc06-b4b7-482f-8b30-8a06e250e68e'}, {'anki_id': 1463883760907.0, 'document': 'Glucocorticoids inhibit production of inflammatory prostaglandins by cyclooxygenase', 'ankihub_id': '179ed7bf-e11e-4382-bf68-a2d1d5219fa1'}, {'anki_id': 1474580751548.0, 'document': 'Leukotrienes C 4 , D 4 , and E 4 increase airway vascular permeability, mucus production, and bronchoconstriction ( bronchospasm ) Especially C4 and D4', 'ankihub_id': '7a5ab614-eaa5-4ea9-a6b4-9ce4bd2ed438'}, {'anki_id': 1474571803096.0, 'document': 'Are 2nd generation H 1 receptor antagonists associated with drowsiness ? No (do not cross BBB therefore less sedation) Also have less anti-muscarinic, anti-serotonergic, and less anti-α 1 -adrenergic properties', 'ankihub_id': 'f2705eb0-dd71-4c5a-a6b4-639b8c13f2e6'}, {'anki_id': 1550409492355.0, 'document': 'Mild / moderate migraine headache = NSAIDs/Acetaminophen::drug class Moderate / severe migraine headache = triptans/ergots::drug class', 'ankihub_id': 'd6d75626-badf-4061-822d-b4339bc31d4e'}, {'anki_id': 1474580736503.0, 'document': 'A major step in the production of leukotrienes is the conversion from arachidonic acid (AA) to 5-HPETE by the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase Immediately after it can be converted to pro-inflammatory leukotrienes (LTC 4 , LTD 4 , LTE 4 ) or chemotactic biomediators (LTB 4 , 5HETE)', 'ankihub_id': 'ff9dacea-e5cb-42b6-9171-9eb0386e7644'}, {'anki_id': 1499356681525.0, 'document': 'Iloprost and epoprostenol are prostacyclin (PGI 2 ) analogues that can be used to treat pulmonary hypertension - Leukotriene D4-receptor antagonists', 'ankihub_id': '6c68205c-fd2b-4656-aa25-1f00053cc401'}, {'anki_id': 1474571715642.0, 'document': '1st generation H 1 receptor antagonists , especially diphenhydramine , may be used as a(n) sleep aid Including doxylamine', 'ankihub_id': '9ce7ed11-936f-45ef-b851-1729fc01f149'}, {'anki_id': 1461624946809.0, 'document': 'Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are effective at reducing both nocturnal and meal-stimulated secretion of acid and thus suppress H + secretion to a greater extent than H 2 receptor blockers', 'ankihub_id': '06e19d1f-cb5e-4e1a-9fca-c36ba492df35'}, {'anki_id': 1462061251872.0, 'document': 'Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects via the inhibition of the release of histamine and serotonin from mast cells and platelets', 'ankihub_id': '472c62b4-27c3-46d9-86a0-2126cf5996f2'}, {'anki_id': 1462327651340.0, 'document': 'In diabetes , osmotic damage may occur when glucose in tissue is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase - e.g., ome prazole , lanso prazole , esome prazole , panto prazole , dexlanso prazole - Patients on proton pump inhibitors have an increased risk of pneumonia and C. difficile infection', 'ankihub_id': '3e316a34-d8a3-46b6-a0b6-bd76f69a664b'}, {'anki_id': 1474571774976.0, 'document': 'Adverse effects of 1st generation H 1 receptor antagonists may be more common and more severe in elderly patients', 'ankihub_id': 'af6f668a-0001-4ff7-b2c3-3543c6f97ff5'}, {'anki_id': 1520901347807.0, 'document': 'Dihydroergotamine is not frequently used for migraine treatment due to its significant side effect profile, including gangrene and vasospastic angina - Dihydroergotamine constricts vascular smooth muscle via stimulation of both α 1 adrenergic receptors (partial agonist) and serotonergic receptors (5-HT 1b/d ) - AKA Prinzmetal angina', 'ankihub_id': '8a4a67dc-ef4a-4d9a-97b9-c538c20a40bb'}, {'anki_id': 1474509405173.0, 'document': 'Respiration may be possible at week 25 (canalicular period)', 'ankihub_id': '05a7f02a-99a8-43b3-afc2-8acf3e7afb99'}, {'anki_id': 1471990453854.0, 'document': 'PGE 1 (alprostadil) may be administered to patients with D-transposition of great vessels to maintain a PDA until definitive surgical repair is performed Without surgical intervention, most infants die within the first few months of life', 'ankihub_id': '4691d788-ea18-40a6-aa4a-d70a0649c442'}, {'anki_id': 1484623918068.0, 'document': '40% of deaths related to child abuse or neglect occur in children < 1 year(s) old', 'ankihub_id': '232831e7-9edb-4ef8-a0ee-225d96194d46'}, {'anki_id': 1485389816164.0, 'document': 'Triptans may cause coronary vasospasm as an adverse effect May trigger Prinzmetal (variant) angina', 'ankihub_id': '4d052977-27f7-4a09-ba21-d1a5e52c84a4'}, {'anki_id': 1553944555323.0, 'document': 'Hypertensive urgency = treated with PO::PO/IV Hypertensive emergency = treated with IV::PO/IV - Emergency = end-organ damage signs - The most commonly used drugs to treat hypertensive emergency are nitroprusside, labetalol, and nicardipine.', 'ankihub_id': '5a8d1211-1842-4933-b30b-f221e3f16526'}, {'anki_id': 1482030348639.0, 'document': 'Histamine is released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa', 'ankihub_id': 'e0de8099-7b40-46b7-a573-b0353262a967'}, {'anki_id': 1485389780620.0, 'document': 'The pain in migraines is mediated by vasoactive peptides on meningeal vessels , which cause vaso dilation e.g., CGRP, substance P, neurokinin A', 'ankihub_id': '45a3ee70-0ee3-4e1b-9753-6921e27b5f52'}, {'anki_id': 1521591883921.0, 'document': 'Gallbladder hypomotility is primarily associated with what kind of gallstone? Cholesterol gallstones - Hypomotility promotes the precipitation and accumulation of particulate material (e.g., calcium monohydrate crystals, calcium bilirubinate, mucus) resulting in the formation of biliary sludge - Sludge can be supersaturated with either cholesterol or calcium bilirubinate, but cholesterol stones are technically more common (~80%) Cholesterol gallstones: ©️ Dr. Jian-Hua Qiao , all rights reserved, via Flickr (used with permission', 'ankihub_id': '854a48d1-fe92-4eec-a24a-777b742b4e0c'}, {'anki_id': 1479267465747.0, 'document': 'Cromolyn sodium and nedocromil prevent mast cell degranulation (used for asthma prophylaxis)', 'ankihub_id': '680689e2-b9cf-42bb-8e76-55cde831ccb3'}, {'anki_id': 1474580787193.0, 'document': 'What is the route of administration of leukotriene D4-receptor antagonists (e.g., montelukast, zafirlukast)? Corticospinal tract 2. Medial lemniscus 3. Abducens nerve (CN VI) Medial pontine syndrome - AKA middle alternating hemiplegia - The medial "M" tracts and CN VI suggests medial pons; larger lesions may involve the facial nerve as well - Medial pontine syndrome involves occlusion of the paramedian branches of the basilar artery. Involvement of : - Corticospinal tract may present as a contralateral spastic hemiparesis - Medial lemniscus may present as a contralateral loss of tactile, position, and vibration sense - Fibers of CN VI (abducens) may present as a medial strabismus', 'ankihub_id': '84907f37-c1cd-43a5-9d03-b593ddb5ddb3'}, {'anki_id': 1462380628768.0, 'document': 'One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is hypertension , which is a result of an upregulation of α 1 -adrenergic receptors , causing increased sensitivity of blood vessels to catecholamines Cortisol mediates the upregulation of α 1 receptors on arterioles', 'ankihub_id': 'b3fa292b-8c06-4660-9753-9d6cfb475cf2'}, {'anki_id': 1497307489656.0, 'document': 'The most common side effect of filgrastim is bone pain Ruptured spleen, ARDS, and alveolar hemorrhage can also result', 'ankihub_id': '9d4d9cd6-6cbc-4f88-a724-c103b98d5d29'}, {'anki_id': 1489962674114.0, 'document': 'Side effects of danazol include weight gain, edema, acne , hirsutism , and masculinization ( androgenic effects)', 'ankihub_id': 'b126d7b5-48de-4738-b671-03b6115bb280'}, {'anki_id': 1487640108934.0, 'document': 'Which leukotrienes mediate vasoconstriction , bronchospasm , and increased vascular permeability ? Methylergonovine : hypertension Carboprost : asthma - Met Hy lergonovine = Hy pertension - C A rboprost = A sthma - The first-line uterotonic is oxytocin, which is generally administered via intravenous infusion. If oxytocin and bimanual massage fail, the next step is to administer other uterotonic agents - Methylergonovine is an uterotonic drug that causes smooth muscle constriction, uterine contraction, and vasoconstriction. Because vasoconstriction can cause hypertension, a history of hypertension (e.g., preeclampsia) is a contraindication to methylergonovine - Carboprost is a synthetic prostaglandin that stimulates uterine contraction. Carboprost causes bronchoconstriction , and asthma is a contraindication to its use in this patient', 'ankihub_id': '91d28660-fe35-4223-8c78-f892058d941c'}, {'anki_id': 1499356681316.0, 'document': 'Because PGE 1 is involved in physiological responses of the gut mucosa and the uterine smooth muscle , misoprostol can cause diarrhea as well as uterine contractions Listed as pregnancy category-X drug', 'ankihub_id': '6bb0fcc5-479c-4378-8aeb-b09a2c122bf3'}, {'anki_id': 1474571788333.0, 'document': 'What drug class does loratadine belong to? 2nd generation H 1 receptor antagonists', 'ankihub_id': 'd724f63c-bf50-4bf2-801b-87cba92f76e3'}, {'anki_id': 1483825263574.0, 'document': 'What is the mode of inheritance of juvenile polyposis syndrome ? Order serum B 12 , homocysteine , and methylmalonic acid ::3 - Initial workup for B 12 deficiency begins with serum B 12 testing → methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels should be ordered for those with borderline/inconclusive results - Increased homocysteine AND methylmalonic acid is expected in vitamin B 12 deficiency (only homocysteine is elevated in B 9 deficiency)', 'ankihub_id': 'e6e0705f-4f14-4250-a74c-651cffd73b3c'}, {'anki_id': 1472161064901.0, 'document': 'What is the main treatment for cardiogenic shock? Uterine atony - The first-line uterotonic is oxytocin, which is generally administered via intravenous infusion. If oxytocin and bimanual massage fail, the next step is to administer other uterotonic agents - Methylergonovine is a uterotonic drug that causes smooth muscle constriction, uterine contraction, and vasoconstriction. There are no triggers and no autonomic symptoms Primary stabbing headache - Classic description is that patient can point to spot with one finger - Usually self-limited, does not require specific treatment (indomethacin can be used for frequent attacks) - Contrast with trigeminal neuralgia : usually has sensory triggers, occurs in the V 2 or V 3 nerve distribution - Contrast with cluster headache : usually lasts for hours, associated with rhinorrhea and lacrimation', 'ankihub_id': '4afadcde-cf15-456b-82b6-bdebadf040d9'}, {'anki_id': 1581609764230.0, 'document': 'What is the next step in management of a patient with multiple myeloma and Ca 2+ > 14mg/dL ? Urticaria Gzzz , CC BY-SA 4.0 , via Wikimedia Commons - Urticaria is characterized by raised, round or oval lesions that can change in size and appearance. They often have a red border (flare) and a pale center (wheal) - The condition may be caused by exposure to drugs, food, or other substances. A patient's medical history (e.g., drug, food, substance exposure) is important for diagnosis - A skin biopsy may be performed to confirm the diagnosis (nonspecific and not often done), but the distinctive appearance of the lesions is often enough for diagnosis", 'ankihub_id': '16bd8cd6-4a6b-41cf-b57d-574fa26cda10'}, {'anki_id': 1485382187439.0, 'document': 'Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor poisoning causes flaccid paralysis due to NMJ nicotinic ACh receptor overactivation Give pralidoxime to treat flaccid paralysis due to organophosphate poisoning', 'ankihub_id': '2c71e9d8-f65d-4b8d-9625-96654f1a24bb'}, {'anki_id': 1485042600488.0, 'document': 'Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) may cause anticholinergic side effects, such as tachycardia , urinary retention , dry mouth , and confusion', 'ankihub_id': '06fecd84-12cb-400e-ac91-000e03e5e4c9'}, {'anki_id': 1477011859852.0, 'document': 'Epinephrine causes increased systolic pressure Via α 1 -mediated vasoconstriction', 'ankihub_id': '7aced850-4a75-4531-b7ac-7ea5cad8b7b9'}, {'anki_id': 1505249015747.0, 'document': 'Chronic spontaneous urticaria is treated with a(n) 2nd generation H 1 blocker (e.g., cetirizine) - Spontaneous resolution within 2-5 years - Avoid triggers (e.g., NSAIDs and heat)', 'ankihub_id': '09dab6b3-04c8-4777-aa26-64ca0ae420d0'}, {'anki_id': 1488855069021.0, 'document': 'What acid-base disorder is seen with early (< 12 hours) phases of aspirin (salicylate) toxicity ? Transvaginal ultrasound reveals no intrauterine or extrauterine pregnancy. Repeat serum β-hCG in 2 days - In a viable pregnancy, β-hCG levels should double every 2 days (ectopic and non-viable pregnancies are associated with a slower rise) - Once β -hCG is > 3500 IU/L , a transvaginal ultrasound should be repeated', 'ankihub_id': 'a137b6dc-b3b5-4bfd-bc27-6c293a88bd3c'}, {'anki_id': 1461601584259.0, 'document': 'Metoclopramide can cause QT prolongation and induce torsades de pointes Therefore avoid metoclopramide in patients with prolonged QT', 'ankihub_id': 'e541e197-6543-443f-98c3-4464a44d0ae6'}, {'anki_id': 1471541598687.0, 'document': 'Bradykinin causes arteriolar dilation and venous constriction', 'ankihub_id': 'a1842cc9-022d-450a-879a-7f6fbe86e71b'}, {'anki_id': 1485048804453.0, 'document': 'Which neurotransmitter(s) is/are metabolized by monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B)? Oligohydramnios Premature closure of ductus arteriosus - Decreased production of prostaglandins leads to fetal vasoconstriction and subsequent decreased renal perfusion = oligohydramnios - Particularly with prolonged administration; therefore, patients typically receive indomethacin for < 48 hours - Oligohydramnios is typically transient and resolves without intervention once the medication is discontinued', 'ankihub_id': '16c9dccd-627e-431d-ac0d-263fa200f15a'}, {'anki_id': 1487640124653.0, 'document': 'In general, leukotrienes cause vaso constriction', 'ankihub_id': '3409f661-1ec0-48b4-814b-ef9ec59c90fb'}, {'anki_id': 1476919655451.0, 'document': 'What effect do antimuscarinics have on heart rate ? Quetiapine - Makes you quiet (sedative/fall down) - While all atypical antipsychotics are associated with some degree of sedation (most patients develop tolerance quickly), low-dose quetiapine is often used as a sleep aid - Quetiapine exerts these effects through blockade of α 1 receptors → impaired arteriolar smooth muscle contractility', 'ankihub_id': '16b2c9b0-e70c-436e-b62f-ea4cae681d43'}, {'anki_id': 1485053797165.0, 'document': 'Vortioxetine inhibits the pre-synaptic reuptake of serotonin (5-HT)', 'ankihub_id': '43668464-fe28-4320-88f7-f89cadd83014'}, {'anki_id': 1505931728135.0, 'document': 'What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with confusion and blurry vision after overdosing on an unknown medication? Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes , decreased bowel sounds , and 8 mm pupils bilaterally Anticholinergic toxicity - "Mad as a hatter, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, full as a flask, red as a beet" - May be reversed with physostigmine (cholinesterase inhibitor)', 'ankihub_id': '04a682fe-1f5b-4f8e-b944-8df6569dc794'}, {'anki_id': 1485219977212.0, 'document': 'Most atypical antipsychotics exert their effects by blocking the D 2 dopamine receptor and 5-HT 2A receptor - AKA second generation antipsychotics (SGAs) - The added serotonin receptor binding of SGAs (in addition to D 2 antagonism) reduces the likelihood of extrapyramidal side effects', 'ankihub_id': '16f727ec-bd39-4c68-ad54-8204840db029'}, {'anki_id': 1485226918038.0, 'document': 'Carbidopa decreases the peripheral side effects of levodopa Carbidopa blocks peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine by inhibiting DOPA decarboxylase , therefore reducing adverse effects of peripheral levodopa conversion into dopamine (e.g., nausea, vomiting)', 'ankihub_id': '77b40fe2-c848-43c4-a7c2-1bab9cc33e0e'}, {'anki_id': 1461616559615.0, 'document': 'By what mechanisms can H + secretion still occur in a patient on H 2 receptor blockers ? Acute dystonia AD = sudden onset of muscle spasm, stiffness, oculogyric crisis; these help correct the muscarinic imbalance due to loss of dopamine', 'ankihub_id': '3fd5e534-8618-4517-b6d1-294d64e5873a'}, {'anki_id': 1471541602504.0, 'document': 'Serotonin causes arteriolar constriction Released in response to blood vessel damage to help prevent blood loss', 'ankihub_id': '2342d92d-ce4b-41dc-8b78-5d6745cf56aa'}, {'anki_id': 1461601620907.0, 'document': 'The area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) contains neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptors which are activated by substance P Use aprepitant to block NK1 receptor', 'ankihub_id': '7834834c-7f80-4ee9-bb2e-a20645310d0d'}, {'anki_id': 1520950977724.0, 'document': 'Fetal fibronectin is useful for its very high negative predictive value in assessing for preterm labor i.e., a negative fetal fibronectin test in the 2nd / 3rd trimester helps rule out preterm labor', 'ankihub_id': '3913cc66-016d-4b0c-bb12-91e93428b9fe'}, {'anki_id': 1547916020504.0, 'document': 'Initial treatment of postpartum hemorrhage includes bimanual massage and uterotonics (e.g., oxytocin) - Oxytocin is a first-line agent (imagine squeezing the uterus and associated vessels) - Other agents, such as methylergonovine and carboprost may be administered if oxytocin fails', 'ankihub_id': 'ea47c79c-66c2-4b44-b355-e9e56a3d6f97'}, {'anki_id': 1489961756380.0, 'document': 'What is the mechanism by which combined contraceptives (progestins + estradiol) prevent pregnancy? Inhibit ovulation - Estrogen and progestins inhibit LH / FSH, thus preventing the estrogen surge / LH surge - The hypothalamus has PR and ER receptors - allowing for negative feedback regulation of GnRH - GnRH stimulates production of LH - which stimulates theca interna cells to produce progesterone and androstenedione, and FSH - which stimulates the production of 17β-estradiol', 'ankihub_id': 'ea355755-82e4-41dc-8337-587f8887882b'}, {'anki_id': 1495740310438.0, 'document': 'Cyclophosphamide can be used as an immunosuppressant for the treatment of lupus nephritis , as well as for systemic vasculitides - e.g., eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), microscopic polyangiitis, IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), polyarteritis nodosa - When given for vasculitides, often given with corticosteroids', 'ankihub_id': 'e6ec3e01-9ee7-4006-9cba-37b5d4cb580f'}, {'anki_id': 1556894064101.0, 'document': 'What is first-line treatment for lichen planus ? Nifedipine (dihydropyridine CCB) Due to peripheral vasodilation ; typically used from 32 - 34 weeks when indomethacin is contraindicated due to risk of PDA closure', 'ankihub_id': 'efa42ffb-d01e-4331-bd4f-920bfd871e72'}, {'anki_id': 1476919680971.0, 'document': 'Ipratropium and tiotropium primarily affect the lungs::organ via inhibition of M 3 muscarinic receptors Inhaled muscarinic antagonists', 'ankihub_id': 'a40dc9bc-e856-4da8-bde0-b8fdad79fa19'}, {'anki_id': 1487640120758.0, 'document': 'In general, prostaglandins cause increased vascular permeability', 'ankihub_id': '50d43047-33ff-4ee8-bc45-22f81067add1'}, {'anki_id': 1485226975107.0, 'document': 'Ropinirole is a non-ergot D 2 receptor agonist that is used in initial treatment of Parkinson disease - Has some D 3 agonist activity as well - Preferred over ergot alkaloids (e.g., bromocriptine)', 'ankihub_id': '4fc04be9-1519-4959-8b19-6a941adc3f7a'}, {'anki_id': 1463078730041.0, 'document': 'What is the treatment for septate uterus ? input:
After completing this brick, you will be able to:

Define appetite and satiety, hyperphagia and aphagia, and the dietary Calorie.
List the two major systems of the body involved in weight management and the concept of anorexigenic and orexigenic compounds.
Describe the role of appetite and metabolic rate in the maintenance of long-term energy, balance, and fat storage, and list and discuss the three normal components of energy expenditure.
List the anorexigenic hormones and the one known orexigenic hormone and their main secretagogue or mode of release, and briefly discuss their putative mechanisms of action.
Describe the importance of the hypothalamus in the control of appetite, list its three main nuclei that have been implicated for appetite control, and discuss the influence of leptin and ghrelin on the arcuate nucleus.
Describe Prader-Willi syndrome and the importance of the hypothalamus in the development of the related hyperphagia.
Case Connection
“I’m frustrated. I can’t lose weight,” TR says. “I cut back on the sugared drinks and chips, but I’m still stuck on 150 pounds. What can I do? My 25th college reunion is coming up and I’ve got to take off 10 pounds. Got a magic pill?”

What advice can you give TR to maximize her success at losing weight? Consider your answer as you read, and we’ll revisit at the end of the brick.

Go to Conclusion
How Is Appetite Controlled?
Our bodies are quite well regulated with feedback controls for our senses of both hunger and satiety (ie, feeling well fed)—all without conscious effort. They are like machines that are continually working and in need of steady fuel. When we lie down to sleep, our bodies don’t switch off with us; in fact, our bodies use that time to rebuild and store some of what we’ve fed it that day. But note that these reflexes were designed over millions of years of evolution, with the goal of avoiding starvation. In modern times, obesity is a bigger threat, especially in developed countries, so many of these “survival” reflexes can be harmful to us, leading to metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

How do hunger and satiety work? They are signals that our bodies use to control our appetite. Hunger is our body telling us that we need more fuel and satiety that we have enough fuel for now. This intricate balance is controlled by both hormonal and neural gastrointestinal (GI) input.

These systems are a continuous feedback loop. In this complex system, hormones serve as signals between cells of the GI tract and pancreas and the hypothalamus. When we eat, our GI system works to break down the fuel we just fed our bodies so our cells can use these various nutrients (ie, monosaccharides, fatty acids, and amino acids). Once our GI system has sensed that we have given it enough fuel, it sends a signal back to the hypothalamus to say that we are now “full,” and the hypothalamus in turn sends the satiety signal that tells us to stop eating… that is, until our cells need more fuel!

Which two systems control appetite?
Appetite is controlled by the hypothalamus and cells of the GI system.
How Is Appetite Balanced with Metabolic Expenditure?
Why do our bodies require so much fuel? Well, functions such as respiration, circulation, and digestion don’t come “free of charge” (ie, they require energy). In this section, we will discuss the three main types of energy expenditure, including resting metabolic rate (RMR), the cost of digestion, and activity-related expenditure like daily activities and exercise (Figure 1).


Figure 1
Credit: ©ScholarRx

Resting Metabolic Rate
By simply existing (or restfully sleeping), our bodies are constantly working. Our cells are functioning to keep us breathing, keep our hearts working, dispose of cellular waste, and more. This basic state of existing uses calories and is known as the resting metabolic rate (RMR). Each person’s RMR differs based on body composition. A bodybuilder who is constantly lifting weights (and has lots of muscle) will have a higher RMR than a sedentary adult, because it takes more energy to keep the bodybuilder’s cells working. RMR can account for 1300-2000 kcal/d for a young adult, depending on age, weight, and height. It is about two-thirds of your daily energy expenditure overall. However, it drops with aging, perhaps by as much as 30%.

Let’s back up for a moment to go over the important distinction between calorie and Calorie (note the uppercase C). First, they are both units of energy. The physics calorie (lowercase) is the energy required to increase the temperature of 1 g of water by 1°C. The dietary Calorie (uppercase) is equal to 1000 calories (also known as a kilocalorie, or kcal) and is the energy required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water by 1°C. The amount of energy in a calorie is too small to approximate the energy content of food, so the larger Calorie is used. We’ll go with kcal to avoid any confusion.

Diet-Induced Thermogenesis
Diet-induced thermogenesis is the energy used by the GI system to break down, digest, transport, and store the food eaten. Diet-induced thermogenesis accounts for 10%-15% of daily energy expenditure. Protein has a higher thermic effect than carbohydrates or fats because protein use is a more complex process.

Activity-Related Energy Expenditure
So far, the energy usage is mostly beyond our control. How can we increase our energy expenditure if we want to lose weight? First, the energy used during activities of daily living (ADLs), including eating, bathing, dressing, toilet use, and routine movement, is called non-exercise–associated thermogenesis (NEAT). NEAT is about 300-600 kcal/d and can account for differences in weight gain or loss in two individuals with identical caloric intake and RMR (ie, one burns more or fewer calories doing ADLs than the other does, so they may gain or lose weight at the same caloric intake). You can increase NEAT by pacing or standing rather than sitting in a chair all day. NEAT does not include formal exercise, such as running, lifting weights, and swimming. These can expend a wide range of energy, from 150 kcal/h (slow walking) to >1500 kcal/h (intense rowing or running). Increasing NEAT and exercising are both ways we can increase our energy use, so they are often the focus of weight loss programs.

What factors into NEAT?
NEAT includes any calories burned that are related to ADLs and not specific exercise or resting metabolic rate (things like walking to and from the car).
How Is Our Appetite Regulated?
No matter what our energy expenditure, our level of intake is key to the above balance, and this is regulated by appetite. So how is appetite regulated at a physiologic level? Most important is a group of hormones. The hormones we’ll discuss can be categorized as orexigenic (stimulating hunger) or anorexigenic (inducing satiety). Figure 2 provides a schematic of basic hormonal interactions.

Figure 2
Credit: ©ScholarRx

Orexigenic Hormones
Orexigenic hormones increase appetite. Ghrelin is the main hormone that makes us hungry. Ghrelin is secreted by gastric cells before a meal to stimulate appetite and increase food intake by acting on the hypothalamus. During periods of starvation, fasting, and weight loss, ghrelin is increased.

Mnemonic
To remember the hunger hormone ghrelin: If you’re starving, fasting, or losing weight, your stomach is probably ghrowlin’.
Use your stomach to remember the effect of ghrelin.
Clinical Correlation
Sleep deprivation can cause increased levels of ghrelin. It’s important to keep this in mind when dieting or trying to lose weight, because losing sleep can contribute to weight gain.

Orexin acts on the lateral hypothalamus with the overall effects of promoting wakefulness as well as stimulating the drug and food reward centers of the brain.

Clinical Correlation
Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and is caused by a decrease in orexin (remember, orexin promotes wakefulness).

Anorexigenic Hormones
Leptin and insulin are the main hormones that make us feel sated and promote weight loss, but others with primary functions elsewhere in the body have also been implicated in causing satiety.

Leptin. Leptin is secreted by fat cells based on the amount of fat stored in those cells. Leptin then acts on the arcuate nucleus (in the hypothalamus) to decrease appetite and increase energy expenditure. Because it is an indicator of fat storage, leptin acts long-term to decrease appetite based on the amount of fat stored. Without leptin, the result is hyperphagia, or an abnormally increased appetite for food (that may be associated with hypothalamic injury).

Clinical Correlation
Dieters have reduced leptin levels, which makes things hard by increasing appetite and decreasing energy expenditures.

Insulin. Insulin is also anorexigenic; however, insulin has more critical effects, such as increasing the uptake of glucose from the blood into cells as well as increasing cellular enzyme functions for energy storage (eg, fat and glycogen synthesis). Insulin levels fluctuate throughout the day to decrease appetite based on the amount of food eaten that particular day.

Which two hormones are anorexigenic?
Leptin and insulin are anorexigenic.
Adiponectin and Cholecystokinin. Adiponectin is a fat-derived hormone that functions to decrease hepatic gluconeogenesis (formation of glucose from noncarbohydrate molecules like amino acids) and increase fatty acid oxidation. Cholecystokinin (CCK), secreted by the I cells of the duodenum and the jejunum, is essential for proper digestion but has also been proposed to have central nervous system effects related to satiety. Both adiponectin and CCK are anorexigenic.

Peptide YY. Peptide YY, part of the PP family, is secreted by intestinal L cells after a meal and acts to decrease appetite via direct action on the hypothalamus as well as direct inhibition of ghrelin secretion. Peptide YY also acts to inhibit pancreatic enzyme secretion, so it limits food digestion.

Glucagon-Like Peptide-1. GLP-1 functions to increase insulin secretion, thereby having an overall anorexigenic effect. For short-term control of appetite, insulin works closely with both GLP-1 and CCK to mediate the hypothalamic feeding centers.

Oxyntomodulin. Oxyntomodulin is secreted by intestinal cells in response to food intake to decrease appetite and food consumption following food intake.

Non-Hormonal Appetite Control
Hormones are the most important appetite-controlling factors. However, newer research and theories posit that an increase in glucose, amino acids, or lipids can directly decrease the appetite without hormonal control. The idea behind these theories is that our bodies can sense when we have enough of each essential nutrient, leading to an overall short-term decrease in appetite. The precise mechanisms for this remain under study.

Where Are Hunger and Satiety Centers Located in the Brain?
Certain regions of the brain are essential to balance appetite. Some areas inherently control appetite without outside influence, and some regions respond to and produce appetite-regulating hormones. In addition, metabolic substrate levels may also influence the brain’s control of appetite.

Hypothalamic Nuclei
In the hypothalamus, two important nuclei work in tandem to keep the appetite in equilibrium:

The lateral nucleus causes hunger as its baseline function and is further stimulated by ghrelin (which increases hunger) and inhibited by leptin (which decreases hunger).
In contrast, the ventromedial nucleus causes satiety at baseline and is stimulated by leptin (which decreases hunger and overall food intake).
Lesions in either of these nuclei (eg, due to a stroke) may result in opposite predictable outcomes. Destruction of the lateral nucleus causes anorexia and aphagia (inability or refusal to swallow). Destruction of the ventromedial nucleus leads to hyperphagia. This has been shown in animal research. Figure 3 shows that, in animal experiments, a lesion of the lateral hypothalamus leads to aphagia and anorexia (a thin rat), while lesions of the ventromedial nucleus leads to hyperphagia and obesity (a fat rat).


Figure 3
Credit: ©ScholarRx

Mnemonic
To remember which clinical outcome results from injury to which hypothalamic nucleus:
Lesions of the LATERAL nucleus cause you to shrink LATERALly.
Lesions of the VENTROMEDIAL nucleus cause you to grow VENTRally and MEDIALly.
Which clinical outcome results from injury to the lateral hypothalamus? Which results from injury to the ventromedial hypothalamus?
Arcuate Nucleus
The arcuate nucleus plays a role in appetite control because it has receptors for both leptin and insulin, the main anorexigenic hormones. When stimulated, the arcuate nucleus produces pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC), neuropeptide Y, agouti-related protein, and ghrelin, all of which contribute to appetite equilibrium.

What Happens When Appetite Regulatory Systems Fail?
Prader-Willi syndrome is a relatively rare genetic abnormality that results from the deletion of part of chromosome 15. When this happens, ghrelin secretion becomes upregulated as well as unregulated and unbalanced. The overall increase in ghrelin leads to an insatiable appetite (Figure 4). Children with Prader-Willi syndrome do not get proper satiety cues, and consequently they can eat themselves to death. The parents of these children typically have to lock the pantry and fridge to prevent them from binge eating everything they can get their hands on. Most of these children are obese and at increased risk for early-onset type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Ghrelin inhibits anorexigenic neurons in the arcuate nucleus (these neurons stimulate medial area involved in satiety via POMC)', 'ankihub_id': 'ec165a5b-3f1f-475f-a8f8-fb8de5c2b3f4'}, {'anki_id': 1481418798641.0, 'document': 'Stimulation of the lateral area of the hypothalamus is inhibited by leptin " L eptin inhibits L ateral makes you L ean" - “Beta brings in, Alpha allows out” - ECF → ICF (insulin, β-agonists) - ICF → ECF (hyperosmolarity, exercise, cell lysis)', 'ankihub_id': '0822c300-101b-4340-88d7-63a87e0c7618'}, {'anki_id': 1462996133513.0, 'document': 'The dominant hormone produced during the first trimester is hCG', 'ankihub_id': '4826c92c-31b9-4a21-a672-50d1fa624a8d'}, {'anki_id': 1462810025802.0, 'document': 'In response to sleep deprivation , ghrelin secretion is increased', 'ankihub_id': '0b056fe1-81b9-41c2-9b17-593352949854'}, {'anki_id': 1496608251089.0, 'document': 'Klumpke palsy::Condition is due to traction or tear of the lower trunk ( C8-T1 roots)', 'ankihub_id': '5f9a916e-d11e-4b2a-a628-e33415a9e065'}, {'anki_id': 1482021928703.0, 'document': 'Which nutrient stimulates glucose-insulinotropic peptide secretion ? All three (Glucose, Fat, Protein) :)::Glucose, Fat, Protein Specifically oral glucose; somatostatin and GIP are the only GI hormones that respond to all three nutrients', 'ankihub_id': '5245785a-2d03-4b78-b768-8f31d6e4dc4f'}, {'anki_id': 1462053298193.0, 'document': 'Chronically elevated levels of ACTH cause hypertrophy/hyperplasia of the adrenal cortex', 'ankihub_id': '5d0365d8-c165-493a-b4bc-a105819b25a3'}, {'anki_id': 1482021942521.0, 'document': 'Glucose-insulinotropic peptide decreases gastric H + secretion (exocrine effect) Hence also known as gastric inhibitory peptide', 'ankihub_id': '96f7ce6e-673c-42bc-b4b7-dc847f7e5962'}, {'anki_id': 1482021920866.0, 'document': 'Glucose-insulinotropic peptide (GIP) is secreted from K cells in the duodenum and jejunum - Also known as gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) - Glu K ose-insulinotropi K peptide', 'ankihub_id': 'c26fbc4e-3426-49d0-b86f-5b9dd19d69e4'}, {'anki_id': 1485140426447.0, 'document': 'Treatment for binge eating disorder is CBT ± either SSRI s or lisdexamfetamine Topiramate can also be used', 'ankihub_id': 'f4fa440f-f2ad-4273-adde-4e7971a52fd6'}, {'anki_id': 1519710008034.0, 'document': 'Which thyroid imbalance presents with abnormal uterine bleeding and infertility ? Both hyper and hypothyroidism :) Both can present with oligomenorrhea, but: - Hypothyroidism is more associated with menorrhagia - Hyperthyroidism is more associated with amenorrhea', 'ankihub_id': '8d2dae57-07fc-422a-9c4f-1d10f8a94239'}, {'anki_id': 1482021864452.0, 'document': 'Cholecystokinin secretion is stimulated by fatty acids and amino acids', 'ankihub_id': 'd08e3811-b1b0-4d06-95dd-28814ad1eb28'}, {'anki_id': 1462986834932.0, 'document': 'In the granulosa cells of the ovary, testosterone is converted to 17β-estradiol::specific via the enzyme aromatase - LH stimulates activity of cholesterol desmolase in theca cells, which converts cholesterol into pregnenolone - Theca cells make pregnenolone into progesterone (via 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase) which is secreted - Theca cells eventually make pregnenolone into androstenedione (steroid synthesis pathway) which diffuses into nearby granulosa cells - Granulosa cells convert androstenedione → testosterone (via 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase) → 17β-estradiol (via aromatase) - FSH stimulates aromatase', 'ankihub_id': '9e889fba-7bc5-46b9-ad6b-0390a50c7596'}, {'anki_id': 1540593668259.0, 'document': 'What adrenal hormone is often increased in patients with anorexia nervosa ? Cortisol Gonadal axis ↓LH pulsatility ↓Estrogens ↓Androgens Adrenal axis ↑Cortisol no change in DHEAS Growth hormone GH resistance (↑ GH/ ↓IGF-1) Appetite-regulating hormones ↓Leptin ↑Ghrelin ↑PYY', 'ankihub_id': '01a4800c-2257-48cb-8e31-a573d3f9dbbf'}, {'anki_id': 1461875856182.0, 'document': 'What is the effect of hypoglycemia and starvation on growth hormone secretion ? Increased Stimulatory Factors Inhibitory Factors ↓ Glucose ↑ Glucose ↓ FFA ↑ FFA Fasting Obesity Exercise GH Stress Obesity Sleep Senescence α-adrenergic agonists Pregnancy Sex hormones Somatostatin', 'ankihub_id': '46c371aa-6df2-4e6a-a6f7-8106061a1098'}, {'anki_id': 1482021827543.0, 'document': 'Cholecystokinin (CCK) is secreted from I cells in the duodenum and the jejunum', 'ankihub_id': '95226eaf-4021-439e-8e67-db7945ac82ce'}, {'anki_id': 1517408106259.0, 'document': 'The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for releasing the hormone GnRH Failure of this area to release GnRH → arrested sexual development, impotence, amenorrhea', 'ankihub_id': '85fe358d-a7fb-45a9-a07b-3f0ed892f02a'}, {'anki_id': 1486596675590.0, 'document': 'During the 6th week of gestation, the midgut herniates through the umbilical ring Comes back in the 10th week', 'ankihub_id': '24808b7a-d79b-42f9-901c-c8f25bbe3fd8'}, {'anki_id': 1483930553495.0, 'document': 'Hypothalamic secretion of GnRH is mediated by the preoptic nucleus and arcuate nucleus - Secreted into hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal blood; also secreted by arcuate nuclei - These nuclei are absent in Kallman syndrome due to a variety of mutations (e.g., anosmin-1) in proteins that facilitate the migration of GnRH neurons from the olfactory placode and along the olfactory nerves to the hypothalamus', 'ankihub_id': '6521991d-9884-4d57-93f6-8af2456d0e00'}, {'anki_id': 1474571753825.0, 'document': '1st generation H 1 receptor antagonists may stimulate appetite and cause weight gain due to anti- serotonergic effects Serotonin regulation of satiety is a separate pathway from leptin regulation of satiety', 'ankihub_id': '06434270-5bb5-4774-8b05-00947e0b0f59'}, {'anki_id': 1469211952966.0, 'document': 'What pathology is characterized by insatiable appetite (hyperphagia), obesity, intellectual disability , and hypogonadism ? Prader-Willi syndrome - Complications include OSA, T2DM, choking episodes secondary to hyperphagia, gastric disention / rupture - Other features include hypotonia (weak suck as an infant), short stature , facial dysmorphia (almond-shaped eyes, narrow forehead, downturned mouth with a thin upper lip), developmental delay , and behavioral problems (temper tantrums, skin picking)', 'ankihub_id': 'e44ce76c-4b6e-4457-ace9-1ceb178c10c5'}, {'anki_id': 1482022010871.0, 'document': 'What effect does somatostatin have on insulin and glucagon secretion ? Decreased secretion Also inhibits gastrin secretion', 'ankihub_id': '26535c37-7bf3-4716-a0fc-d9184bfb668f'}, {'anki_id': 1482021853417.0, 'document': 'One function of cholecystokinin is to decrease gastric emptying Allows adequate time for fat digestion and absorption', 'ankihub_id': '337107ab-aa44-4261-97bd-74f91c183338'}, {'anki_id': 1461870100824.0, 'document': 'Hypothalamic hormones stimulate or inhibit the release of anterior pituitary hormones', 'ankihub_id': '87a989e2-fa00-4bbd-8777-5252dd9544e6'}, {'anki_id': 1584134575365.0, 'document': 'Intracellular accumulation of triglycerides and FFAs contributes to insulin resistance in obesity via inhibition of insulin signaling - Excess glucose and FFAs also accumulates in β cells leading to insulin resistance * adipocytes, hepatocytes, muscle cells', 'ankihub_id': '0aa3637b-6bf8-4dfe-90de-62e457ebb68b'}, {'anki_id': 1482021831523.0, 'document': 'One function of cholecystokinin is to increase secretion of pancreatic enzymes Acts on neural muscarinic pathways to cause pancreatic secretion', 'ankihub_id': '570b7e2d-2dcf-4e2c-a7a3-00dc4d116cbe'}, {'anki_id': 1462122670792.0, 'document': 'Insulin is packaged in secretory granules of the Golgi apparatus with C-peptide', 'ankihub_id': '768c5d93-e3ab-4f3a-8313-bcf7066d06b4'}, {'anki_id': 1461875983115.0, 'document': 'The synthesis of growth hormone is inhibited by somatostatin, its release-inhibiting hormone Somatostatin is also known as somatotropin release-inhibiting factor (SRIF) Stimulatory Factors Inhibitory Factors ↓ Glucose ↑ Glucose ↓ FFA ↑ FFA Fasting Obesity Exercise GH Stress Obesity Sleep Senescence α-adrenergic agonists Pregnancy Sex hormones Somatostatin', 'ankihub_id': '271ad635-bce0-4557-9524-f4aad502b644'}, {'anki_id': 1476500626106.0, 'document': 'How much energy (kcal) can be produced from 1g of protein or carbohydrate (e.g., whey)? 4 kcal', 'ankihub_id': '869ee7be-2f6a-4c02-9be1-7bdd5384b2d8'}, {'anki_id': 1461880625384.0, 'document': 'Destruction of the hypothalamus or interruption of the hypothalamic-hypophyseal tract results in prolactin excess by causing loss of tonic inhibition by dopamine - e.g., destruction by non-malignant infiltrative lesions like sarcoidosis or histiocytosis X - Decreased dopamine → decreased inhibition of prolactin secretion from anterior pituitary', 'ankihub_id': 'a192131e-60d5-4ae7-80ac-5de208743c2f'}, {'anki_id': 1462131701878.0, 'document': 'Glucagon acts on the liver (primarily) and adipose tissue - Liver : to promote gluconeogenesis , glycogen breakdown and decrease in glycolysis - Adipose : increased activity of adipose triglyceride lipase (leads to more non-esterified fatty acids in the blood) and reduced malonyl-CoA', 'ankihub_id': 'fcf209e6-2878-41e2-9f33-089d764f98cd'}, {'anki_id': 1482021878472.0, 'document': 'The minimum fragment necessary for biologic activity of cholecystokinin (CCK) is the C-terminal heptapeptide Whereas the minimum fragment necessary for biological activity of gastrin is the C-terminal tetrapeptide', 'ankihub_id': '19381ea9-5340-41d4-bd1b-8b5eb821e3da'}, {'anki_id': 1462326996658.0, 'document': 'What age group is most commonly affected by type 1 DM ? < 30 years old Usually manifests in childhood with features of insulin deficiency', 'ankihub_id': 'eefdc140-d1b7-49de-903b-44da3b5a0a0d'}, {'anki_id': 1475982741557.0, 'document': 'Hormone sensitive lipase is regulated via negative feedback by insulin', 'ankihub_id': 'ffde90e8-c0cb-4bc3-aaab-7c95d3632448'}, {'anki_id': 1462130433532.0, 'document': 'Glucagon , an endocrine hormone , is a member of a family of peptides that includes the GI hormones secretin and GIP', 'ankihub_id': '08dcffe3-a4e6-4623-974e-ee8191d5997a'}, {'anki_id': 1481418757045.0, 'document': 'The supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus primarily makes ADH - Lesions here cause diabetes insipidus - May also secrete oxytocin to a lesser extent - * per NBME form 30 ADH can also be released from the paraventricular nuclei SAD POX : S upraoptic = AD H, P araventricular = ox ytocin', 'ankihub_id': '7b615181-513d-40e2-a913-c212cddac8a3'}, {'anki_id': 1482021961866.0, 'document': 'Somatostatin is secreted from D cells in the GI mucosa Also secreted by the hypothalamus and pancreatic δ cells', 'ankihub_id': 'eac4421e-ecd5-4f0d-a113-419d73db5036'}, {'anki_id': 1476502544746.0, 'document': 'How much energy (kcal) can be produced from 1g of fat ? 9 kcal 0.9 kg of fat contains approximately 7000 kcal', 'ankihub_id': '9cd2d84c-f2cd-4fb2-ab74-4f627e43fb68'}, {'anki_id': 1462849382382.0, 'document': 'Patients on sulfonylureas are at increased risk of hypoglycemia if they have renal failure - Sulfonylureas are largely excreted in urine → if there is renal failure, sulfonylureas will have a longer half-life → more insulin release and increased likelihood of hypoglycemia - Liver failure is also a contraindication because sulfonylureas are metabolized by CYP450 (specifically CYP2C9)', 'ankihub_id': '6dd38b5e-07ec-47c7-926d-f1e25f32247a'}, {'anki_id': 1461869987440.0, 'document': 'The hypothalamus is connected to the pituitary gland by a thin stalk called the infundibulum Injury of stalk → increased prolactin levels', 'ankihub_id': 'e007c7f0-26da-435d-9f1a-22b6c50f33ae'}, {'anki_id': 1584562521028.0, 'document': 'Dysfunction of the hypothalamus leads to increased prolactin levels Due to decreased dopamine → decreased inhibition of prolactin secretion from anterior pituitary', 'ankihub_id': '71092bc5-d4aa-4f32-889c-9a405786f23b'}, {'anki_id': 1482115334134.0, 'document': 'Release of the enzymatic component of pancreatic secretion is primarily stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK) Release of the aqueous (HCO 3 - ) component of pancreatic secretion is primarily stimulated by secretin', 'ankihub_id': 'fabd6b7c-9b31-4f4f-91c4-e87c14683aa2'}, {'anki_id': 1481418805098.0, 'document': 'The anterior hypothalamus is controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system', 'ankihub_id': '67153df7-fd4c-464e-95e0-763bdeae4f54'}, {'anki_id': 1584122235393.0, 'document': 'What polypeptide is co-secreted with insulin from β cells and assists in glycemic control? Amylin Amylin inhibits glucagon secretion , delays gastric emptying , and increases satiety', 'ankihub_id': 'b109c221-745b-45b0-977b-8ad301dcf603'}, {'anki_id': 1484016758542.0, 'document': 'What demographic is associated with decreased REM sleep and decreased REM latency ? Elderly patients - Depression decreases REM latency but increases REM sleep - Per FA 2023, elderly patients have increased sleep latency and early awakenings , as well as decreased N3 and REM sleep', 'ankihub_id': '754938a4-acdd-4a74-ab37-4ccb91c02c32'}, {'anki_id': 1461875973910.0, 'document': 'The synthesis of growth hormone is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH), its hypothalamic-releasing hormone', 'ankihub_id': '0bd2379f-5dc9-41b0-b650-89406e145c09'}, {'anki_id': 1462128231420.0, 'document': 'Insulin decreases blood glucose concentration by downregulating gluconeogenesis via increased production of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate Thus in insulin resistance , there is increased hepatic glucose production', 'ankihub_id': '94531c35-d869-4d34-a7bd-ea1a42c595be'}, {'anki_id': 1482021861281.0, 'document': 'One function of cholecystokinin is to potentiate the effects of secretin on HCO 3 - secretion', 'ankihub_id': '0f780388-5d4a-4094-bba9-64548ccc4cb5'}, {'anki_id': 1462913533718.0, 'document': 'What class of diabetic drugs is associated with increased risk of fracture as a possible side effect? Thiazolidinediones (glitazones)', 'ankihub_id': '51f0b8b0-3308-442a-bd57-30760c324fa7'}, {'anki_id': 1462849475077.0, 'document': 'Do GLP-1 agonists and/or DPP-4 inhibitors cause hypoglycemia as a possible side effect? No GLP-1 stimulates glucose-dependent insulin release (does not bypass regulation)', 'ankihub_id': '4b0fb949-0ca4-42d8-8c45-4c99b741c4dc'}, {'anki_id': 1462810098191.0, 'document': 'In response to sleep deprivation , leptin secretion is decreased', 'ankihub_id': '1e0efe09-1ac5-42d9-b676-660b537918b4'}, {'anki_id': 1482021936009.0, 'document': 'Glucose-insulinotropic peptide causes increased release of insulin in response to a(n) oral::oral/IV glucose load (endocrine effect)', 'ankihub_id': '4bed7da7-e613-4be2-bc35-fd63fe4d4783'}, {'anki_id': 1482021686946.0, 'document': 'Gastrin is secreted from G cells in the antrum of the stomach and the duodenum', 'ankihub_id': '8ee35b9f-9c72-4180-8189-2f67d04b1f70'}, {'anki_id': 1475982737323.0, 'document': 'Hormone sensitive lipase is induced by epinephrine , glucagon , and cortisol', 'ankihub_id': 'e6a3beb1-2203-41f2-8553-e3da2ab0cc31'}, {'anki_id': 1524705541467.0, 'document': 'Glucagon , cortisol , and epinephrine induce insulin resistance due to phosphorylation of serine / threonine residues of the insulin receptor and IRS-1 - Both glucagon and catecholamines increase the activity of PKA which phosphorylates serine and threonine residues on targets - TNF-α can also induce insulin resistance via this same mechanism', 'ankihub_id': '08f174c8-2122-4f8a-9c77-091a8ced740c'}, {'anki_id': 1482021846216.0, 'document': 'One function of cholecystokinin is to increase relaxation of the hepatopancreatic sphincter (sphincter of Oddi) Facilitates ejection of bile from the gallbladder into the small intestine', 'ankihub_id': '5e24661d-9ea6-4532-960a-6173661beb32'}, {'anki_id': 1461870794374.0, 'document': 'The six major hormones that are secreted by the anterior lobe of the pituitary may be remembered with the mnemonic FLATPiG F SH L H A CTH T SH P rolactin i G rowth hormone', 'ankihub_id': '3310785c-e9e2-44af-b96c-db8db36184d1'}, {'anki_id': 1540248871113.0, 'document': 'What is the dopamine hypothesis of the etiology of schizophrenia? Increased DA activity and receptors in some brain regions yield positive symptoms Decreased DA activity and receptors in other regions yield negative symptoms', 'ankihub_id': 'd968db18-3d1a-4312-866b-cf84e943b519'}, {'anki_id': 1481418802820.0, 'document': 'Lesion of the anterior hypothalamus results in hyperthermia', 'ankihub_id': '45466836-de0d-4436-8bc5-be77192bfcb6'}, {'anki_id': 1462127805913.0, 'document': 'Increased ATP:ADP ratio in the pancreatic β cell (as a result of glucose metabolism) causes ATP-sensitive K + channels to close , causing membrane depolarization Also allows increased Ca 2+ influx - Certain patients with neonatal diabetes mellitus have mutations in this channel in which elevated glucose levels do not lead to appropriate depolarization and insulin release (treat these patients with sulfonylureas) - Conversely, mutations causing increased affinity for ATP and inappropriate closure of K ATP channels would lead to excessive insulin release and frequent hypoglycemia', 'ankihub_id': 'f5c7a11d-1873-4dbc-806f-45f02fbb6b07'}, {'anki_id': 1461877968926.0, 'document': 'One direct action of growth hormone is decreased glucose uptake into cells, producing a(n) increase in glucose blood concentration - Diabetogenic effect ; growth hormone causes insulin resistance which mimics the effects of diabetes mellitus - Also increases gluconeogenesis', 'ankihub_id': '9b6311cf-e4ef-44b7-b8ff-8710303efcbe'}, {'anki_id': 1481244661094.0, 'document': 'At the optic chiasm , 60% of the optic fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross and project into the contralateral optic tracts Thus the temporal image decussates', 'ankihub_id': 'eb8347e0-1dc2-4a37-bc79-1e48081d0568'}, {'anki_id': 1535306133024.0, 'document': 'Diabetes, gallstones, steatorrhea and hypochlorhydria is suggestive of somatostatinoma::condition - Somato"stasis" = inhibit other GI hormones Because somatostatin (from delta cells) inhibits release of: - Insulin → diabetes - Secretin and CCK → gallstones and steatorrhea - Gastrin → achlorhydria', 'ankihub_id': '14332a3c-3002-4c58-8fcf-35bffb18dbc2'}, {'anki_id': 1550626599904.0, 'document': 'Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) = ↑ anion gap due to ketone bodies No insulin = ↑ ketone bodies Anion gap = [Na + - (Cl - + HCO 3 - )] Normal = 8 - 16 (anion gap) Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS) Type of Patient Young > Elderly; T1DM > T2DM Elderly > Young; T2DM (20% w/o hx of T2DM) Duration < 2 days > 5 days Glucose Hyperglycemia < 800 Severe hyperglycemia > 800 pH Metabolic acidosis pH > 7.3 Serum Osm < 330 > 330 Ketones Ketonemia (elevated beta-hydroxybutyrate) Minimal or negative ketonemia Prognosis < 5% > 50%', 'ankihub_id': '016f382c-3c6a-467c-b9cf-945533c14267'}, {'anki_id': 1461870083093.0, 'document': 'The hypothalamus and anterior pituitary are linked directly by the hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal system', 'ankihub_id': 'aefc9592-fb59-4fa1-8f5e-d6a3726cbfcd'}, {'anki_id': 1462913584874.0, 'document': 'Amylin analogues (e.g., pramlintide) cause decreased gastric emptying', 'ankihub_id': '0a49b354-8aea-4913-b69d-8b46f769f652'}, {'anki_id': 1475966765801.0, 'document': 'Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is regulated via positive feedback by insulin and apolipoprotein C-II', 'ankihub_id': 'dd9388f1-6ee2-402a-b97f-2f7ca6dae252'}, {'anki_id': 1461875931305.0, 'document': 'What is the effect of sleep on growth hormone secretion ? Increased Specifically, stage III and IV sleep Stimulatory Factors Inhibitory Factors ↓ Glucose ↑ Glucose ↓ FFA ↑ FFA Fasting Obesity Exercise GH Stress Obesity Sleep Senescence α-adrenergic agonists Pregnancy Sex hormones Somatostatin', 'ankihub_id': '4391fdd4-8c6e-4aed-ac8a-79939b8182a9'}, {'anki_id': 1462131726115.0, 'document': 'The major factor that stimulates glucagon secretion is hypoglycemia Patients with impaired alpha cell function (e.g., long-standing DM, cystic fibrosis, etc.) are therefore at increased risk of insulin-induced hypoglycemia due to the absence of normal counter-regulatory function', 'ankihub_id': '9876f406-a5e6-48c6-842c-7ce8893b5aa8'}, {'anki_id': 1482021903019.0, 'document': 'One function of secretin is to decrease gastric acid secretion and increase pyloric sphincter contraction Secretin reduces acid secretion by parietal cells AND inhibits secretion of gastrin from G cells, basically acts to prevent further acid spilling into duodenum after food has been digested', 'ankihub_id': '33bed4a8-283a-4a8f-ab37-8ab8f42dad34'}, {'anki_id': 1461870088700.0, 'document': 'Blood from the hypothalamus that contains high concentrations of hypothalamic hormones is delivered directly to the anterior pituitary The anterior pituitary cells are the only cells in the body that receive high concentrations of hypothalamic hormones', 'ankihub_id': 'df089f48-12bf-41d9-ae5c-67cd21eb52a1'}, {'anki_id': 1482021838448.0, 'document': 'One function of cholecystokinin is to increase contraction of the gallbladder Facilitates ejection of bile from the gallbladder into the small intestine', 'ankihub_id': 'f73dd41f-c13e-49a2-a40e-002522c6b996'}, {'anki_id': 1481418763459.0, 'document': 'The paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus primarily secretes oxytocin - Also secretes CRH and TRH SAD POX : - S upraoptic = AD H, - P araventricular = ox ytocin', 'ankihub_id': '3fbc16c5-6e0a-4b05-8cea-68549df99234'}, {'anki_id': 1584884216743.0, 'document': 'Glucagonomas may cause weight loss due to the catabolic action of glucagon (decreased storage of glycogen and fat)', 'ankihub_id': 'faa032e6-7477-4ebd-a825-fb3b8d29a272'}, {'anki_id': 1584883920042.0, 'document': 'Glucagonomas may cause gastrointestinal symptoms due to secretion of glucagon and other molecules (e.g., secretin) E.g., diarrhea, anorexia, abdominal pain', 'ankihub_id': 'b6d69ad5-38dc-43ed-8d23-f9da4eb5a486'}, {'anki_id': 1462913773816.0, 'document': 'SGLT-2 inhibitors , such as canagliflozin, cause increased excretion of urinary glucose (glucosuria) -gliflozin = gl ucose " flozin " (flows in) 2 the urine', 'ankihub_id': '4e815261-2498-468c-a522-31506ddada7c'}, {'anki_id': 1581963733880.0, 'document': 'Primary::Primary/secondary dysmenorrhea is characterized by midline::location pelvic pain May radiate to back and thighs', 'ankihub_id': '2bc5d4d7-887a-4f3c-bc07-60dcaef5d8d2'}, {'anki_id': 1474164845352.0, 'document': 'Increased insulin (fed) leads to decreased cAMP and protein kinase A , thus decreasing activity of fructose bisphosphatase-2 and increasing activity of phosphofructokinase-2', 'ankihub_id': '5ef9d846-402f-41a0-8e90-80e72ee418cf'}, {'anki_id': 1462810116955.0, 'document': 'What is the effect of endocannabinoids on appetite? Increased ("the munchies")', 'ankihub_id': '7f7416d8-eb66-4517-8fd3-41f2c95eb8c3'}, {'anki_id': 1461884779583.0, 'document': 'The most important physiologic stimulus for increasing antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion is increased plasma osmolarity Sensed by osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus Stimulatory Factors Inhibitory Factors ↑ serum osmolarity ↓ serum osmolarity ↓ ECF α-agonist ↓ Glucose level ANP Nicotine Alcohol Opioids Pain Angiotensin II', 'ankihub_id': '45a896ad-e865-4742-b60a-2d3280684f15'}, {'anki_id': 1462037942264.0, 'document': 'Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) acts on thyrotrophs/lactotrophs of the anterior pituitary to stimulate the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and prolactin , respectively Both of which are from the anterior pituitary', 'ankihub_id': 'c88ee988-1395-4010-b0e1-23696d14892b'}, {'anki_id': 1461876244688.0, 'document': 'Growth hormone inhibits its own secretion by stimulating the secretion of somatostatin from the hypothalamus', 'ankihub_id': '0d9d977f-2dc8-4020-aea4-adbd5ebe8c1a'}, {'anki_id': 1493668150043.0, 'document': 'Thyroid hormone increases basal metabolic rate (BMR) and oxygen consumption via increased activity of Na + -K + ATPase - Increases O 2 consumption, RR, body temp; this is why there is weight loss with hyperthyroidism - Primary active transport, therefore utilizes ATP and produces heat', 'ankihub_id': 'ad627ac9-d3d1-46f6-aa7c-8193e45dc86d'}, {'anki_id': 1462128168760.0, 'document': 'The number of insulin receptors is increased in starvation and decreased in obesity Thus measurement of waist circumference / waist-to-hip ratio is an effective indirect assessment of visceral fat to predict insulin resistance', 'ankihub_id': '7a1a96af-a207-4ea5-adf9-1ba018cbed9e'}, {'anki_id': 1474164831303.0, 'document': 'Increased glucagon (fasting) leads to increased cAMP and protein kinase A , thus increasing activity of fructose bisphosphatase-2 and decreasing activity of phosphofructokinase-2', 'ankihub_id': '8b20269d-e66e-41e1-b5ce-114a3e6529e4'}, {'anki_id': 1482021753483.0, 'document': 'Gastrin secretion is inhibited by somatostatin', 'ankihub_id': '6ecc328e-4900-4207-8657-ee864c43444e'}, {'anki_id': 1523240217022.0, 'document': 'Patients with phenylketonuria develop hypopigmentation of what brain nuclei? Negative symptoms - Diagnosis of schizophrenia also requires that the disturbance persists in some form (not necessarily meeting the above criteria) for at least 6 months - Negative symptoms include affective flattening, avolition, anhedonia, asociality, or alogia - Alogia = poverty of speech, Avolition = lack of interest in goal directed behavior', 'ankihub_id': 'a8930445-6de6-4a8f-a140-9236176aab3e'}, {'anki_id': 1474503712016.0, 'document': 'Obstructive sleep apnea may be caused by excess parapharyngeal tissue in adults::age group', 'ankihub_id': '73054066-66a8-44f8-b174-3cb2277637e2'}, {'anki_id': 1488248007419.0, 'document': 'Which arthritis classically involves the PIPs and MCPs ? Testosterone/estrogen will be decreased , LH/FSH will also be decreased (AKA secondary hypogonadism) - Narcotics act directly on the hypothalamus and inhibit the pulsatile release of GnRH, which blocks the release of LH and FSH from the pituitary, affecting the production of testosterone or estrogen from the gonads', 'ankihub_id': '7808288a-5937-45be-9b20-5a7944bc7565'}, {'anki_id': 1462206315422.0, 'document': 'Acromegaly may cause growth of visceral organs , leading to dysfunction', 'ankihub_id': '40d3614c-4c1e-458c-abf9-a49fca22424f'}, {'anki_id': 1476502548954.0, 'document': 'How much energy (kcal) can be produced from 1g of alcohol ? 7 kcal', 'ankihub_id': 'fb074ad4-ecf7-4591-a7e8-7da9bf0e35d9'}, {'anki_id': 1462206436898.0, 'document': 'Growth hormone-secreting adenoma may be diagnosed by lack of GH suppression by oral glucose', 'ankihub_id': 'ea73c111-7042-4f66-b141-632dba9ed552'}, {'anki_id': 1484188901425.0, 'document': 'The characteristics of von Hippel-Lindau disease may be remembered with the mnemonic HARP H emangioblastomas (clumps of capillaries) - Form in the retina, brainstem, cerebellum, and/or spine - High vascularity with hyperchromatic nuclei - When occurs in the retina, can lead to retinal detachment, treat with argon laser phototherapy and cryotherapy if symptomatic - Bright red on gross examination (well-circumscribed, benign, no invasion) - Mutated VHL cannot ubiquitinate HIF1alpha for degradation and therefore cannot prevent angiogenesis → proliferation of hemangioblastomas A ngiomatosis (e.g., cavernous hemangiomas in skin, mucosa, organs) Bilateral R enal cell carcinomas - Clear cell carcinomas - Patients also develop renal cysts P heochromocytomas - Manifest as excess adrenaline and tend to be aggressive', 'ankihub_id': 'a7500201-684d-4c6e-beb2-172c38a3cf00'}, {'anki_id': 1586023336385.0, 'document': 'What is the first-line treatment for gigantism ?
